objtitle.title: *Hecate, or the Night of Enitharmon's Joy*

objdescid.compdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the third one printed in 1795. The first impression in that printing session is *Hecate, or The Night of Enitharmon's Joy* in the Tate Collection (Butlin 316); the second impression of the design is in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery (Butlin 318).

objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression
objinfo.support: wove paperThe leaf bearing the color print is laid down on a backing mat. The inscription and "N G S" collection mark, lower right on the mat, are later additions not by Blake.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Scotland
provenance.price: By transfer from the Royal Scottish Academy; see provenance note below.
provenance.note: Perhaps acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; perhaps acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; possibly the impression (but more probably the impression in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, Butlin 318) acquired by the dealer Joseph Hogarth no later than 1843; possibly the impression (but more probably the impression in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, Butlin 318) briefly in the possession of John Ruskin, c. 1843 but returned to Hogarth; the dealer Colnaghi, Scott & Co., by 1859; given by John Scott of Colnaghi, Scott & Co. to the Royal Scottish Academy in 1862; transferred to the National Gallery of Scotland in 1910.

desc.objtitle: Hecate, or the Night of Enitharmon's Joy, Object 1 (Butlin 317)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Slightly to the right of the center, Enitharmon (or Hecate) sits with her legs drawn up to her chest and crossed, while looking to the left. She appears to be nude except for the gown or cloak draping her legs. Her left hand is holding a book open while pointing to the book’s text. Two nude figures, perhaps a female (left of Enitharmon/Hecate) and a male (right) are behind Enitharmon/Hecate. The female faces right, the male to the left. Their hair is visible, but not their faces. An ass enters from the left and munches on some foliage in the lower left corner of the design. Behind the donkey is a rocky terrain, perhaps the side of a cliff or hill. Nestled within the rocks is a peeking lizard (?) revealing only its head. Behind the lizard and farther up on the rocks is an owl. In the distance on the right, an anthropomorphic bat flies above the heads of the three figures. Even farther in the distance, along the right margin, an outline of another flying creature appears.

component.illusobjdesc: Hecate (or Enitharmon) is pictured sitting on the ground with her legs drawn up and her left leg crossed in front of her right. She appears to be wearing a dark gown or cloak that only covers her legs. Both knees are prominent and her feet are prominent at the gown’s hem; her shoulders and arms are bare. She has long hair and she looks to the left, while her left hand is touching an open book. A curling lock of hair suggests a spiral. Her left index finger points to the book’s text. Her arms are at her sides and her gown obscures her right hand.

A nude and youthful female (?) kneels to the left of Enitharmon (or Hecate). Only her right side, facing right, is visible; her face is behind the central figure's head. She has long hair that cascades over her right shoulder. Her right arm is beside and slightly behind her body, and her right leg is bent at the knee. Her right hand is partially pictured.

A partly obscured youthful and nude male (?) kneels or stands right of Enitharmon (or Hecate). He faces to the left with his head tilted down, and, although the side of his body is visible, his short (?), curly hair obscures his face. His left arm is at his side though slightly in front of his body. Except for part of his left thigh, his legs are not pictured.

An ass or donkey with large pointed ears, open mouth, and partially closed right eye grazes in the left margin. Its head is bent down to eat the vegetation below it, and it stands, strides, or walks to the right with its right leg and hoof in front of its left leg. Its head above the eye and much of its body seem to be covered in fur or shaggy hair.
The rocky terrain in the left side of the design may be a cliff, part of a hill, or part of a larger mountainous range that extends upwards.
The three human figures may be placed on a low mound, most clearly evident just right of the central figure. Apparently the legs of the figure on the right are behind this mound.

To the right of the ass and mostly hidden within a crevice in the rocks, a lizard (or toad or serpent?) peeks out, revealing only its head, facing up and to the right. Its right eye may be raised upwards.
To the right of the ass and above and to the left of the lizard, an owl perches in the rocky terrain and stares out at the viewer.

Above the three human figures, a hairy or furry-faced bat-winged creature flies or hovers overhead. Its large bat wings are fully extended; its mouth may be slightly open. Its fur and beard (?) are spiky, and its expression suggests a threatening or angry attitude. Its nose, moustache, eyebrows, and beard give it an anthropomorphic appearance.
A second flying creature, possibly another bat or bat-like monster, is darkly pictured between the right-most figure's head and the right margin of the design. Only its wings are pictured.
In the lower right corner is an opened book with mottled coloring that suggests an illegible text on the pages.
Much of the landscape appears to be covered with low-growing vegetation, perhaps including grasses, moss, and lichens.
The sky upper right and along the right margin is very dark; this may be a night scene.

lg.l: Fresco W Blake invBlake's signature is inscribed in black ink lower left. It is difficult to see because of the dark and mottled background.
